edu.bu.segrelab.comets
Class CometsRunPanel

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          java.awt.Panel
              java.applet.Applet
                  processing.core.PApplet
                      edu.bu.segrelab.comets.CometsRunPanel
All Implemented Interfaces:
CometsConstants, java.awt.event.FocusListener, java.awt.event.KeyListener, java.awt.event.MouseListener, java.awt.event.MouseMotionListener, java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Runnable, java.util.EventListener, javax.accessibility.Accessible, processing.core.PConstants
public class CometsRunPanel
extends processing.core.PApplet
implements CometsConstants

The CometsRunPanel does all the heavy programmatic lifting of running the simulation. At this level, that entails telling the World2D when to run, updating the graphical output, and processing keyboard and mouse commands.

This is currently written as a Processing PApplet http://www.processing.org which extends the old Java Applet. As such, it has some Issues, especially since it's a heavyweight object (being based on the Java AWT and all) sitting in what I've conceived to be a mostly lightweight (Java Swing) world.

Eventually, I'll roll this into the CometsSetupPanel class somehow. But for now, tucking this functionality in its own little Applet-threaded wrapper seems to make it work okay.

Author:
Bill Riehl
See Also:
Serialized Form

CometsRunPanel

public CometsRunPanel(Comets c)
Constructs a new CometsRunPanel from the current Comets object.

This constructor grabs a pointer to the CometsParameters, World2D, list of cells and models.

Parameters:
c - - the Comets object that owns this one.
Method Detail

setup

public void setup()
This is called automatically by the PApplet startup procedure. It sets up various Processing-centric parameters: applet size, background color, framerate, etc. It also sets the font to be used for drawing on the screen as well as initializing a timestep for use with logfiles, etc.

Overrides:
setup in class processing.core.PApplet

draw

public void draw()
Just like other Applets, this needs a draw() function that gets looped through for the runtime of the program.

If the system is paused, nothing happens. When unpaused, here's the cycle of events:
1. show what cycle count we're on, if applicable
2. take a snapshot, if the slideshow parameters are on //TODO
3. test exit conditions: if the cells are all dead, or we've overrun the cycle limit, stop here
4. tell the World2D to run(). This will update any shared objects (cell list, models, etc).
5. tell the World2D to respawn its media, if we're at the right time.
6. pause if we're supposed to.
7. say how long this cycle took, if we're supposed to.
8. redraw the world

Overrides:
draw in class processing.core.PApplet

endSimulation

public void endSimulation()
When the simulation is ended - for whatever reason - this is run as a cleanup function. It should flush and close all log files and alert the user that the simulation's over.

currentWorldColor

public int currentWorldColor(int x,
                             int y,
                             double[] m)
Gets the current color of the world at space (x, y), relative to the maximum values given in the m array.

Parameters:
x - - x-coordinate of the world
y - - y-coordinate of the world
m - - a 3-element array of double values, used as a coloring threshold.
Returns:
the scaled color of the world as a packed 32-bit integer - like what Processing uses for colors.

redrawWorld

public void redrawWorld()
Redraws the entire world. It first creates a color scale based on whether we're in relative or absolute color mode, then applies it to all spaces.

toggleWorldDisplay

public void toggleWorldDisplay(int delta)
Toggles the world display by a fixed number of steps.
There are a total of N possible elements that can be displayed, where N = the number of nutrients in the media + 1 for the biomass. This is treated like a kind of wheel, where the values 0->N-1 represent the medium, and the value N is the biomass. The delta parameter is used to go up and down and around this wheel. If delta pushed the toggle value up over N, then it rotates back to 0, and likewise if it goes below 0, it rotates back around to N.

The CometsRunPanel then shows values corresponding to what's under that toggle.

Parameters:
delta -

adjustColorScale

public double adjustColorScale(double delta)
Adjusts the color scale in absolute color mode by some delta value. This value is applied equally to all three color channels in the following way:

If the scale value is greater than 1, and delta is > 0 (e.g., it's increasing), then we just apply it directly.

If the scale value is about to go below 1 (e.g., scale + delta < 1), then we just divide the total value in half, regardless of the scale value. This turns the adjustment into an asymptote that approaches 0. Having a color scale <= 0 is Bad News, so we avoid that here.

Likewise, if the scale is less than one, and we add a positive value to it, then we just double the value, until it gets over 1.

Parameters:
delta -
Returns:
the new color scale - this can be printed to the display.
